Thanks Hernán. That's within the MVC family of add-ons, so I'll reassign it to Stefan.

Found the problem! I'm not english or italian language speaker.

public static Pluralizer pluralizer(Locale locale) {
String className = "org.jvnet.inflector.lang." + locale.getLanguage() + ".NounPluralizer";
try

{ Class<?> c = Class.forName(className); return (Pluralizer) c.newInstance(); }

catch (ClassNotFoundException e)

{ return null; }

catch (InstantiationException e)

{ throw new RuntimeException("Problem instantiating " + className, e); } catch (IllegalAccessException e) { throw new RuntimeException("Problem instantiating " + className, e); }

The return null after the ClassNotFoundException is the problem. Maybe you can default to "en" in case of an exception.
I'll try to create a pluralizer for my language (spanish) so you can add it to the distribution. For now I'll copy the org.jvnet.inflector.lang.en.NounPluralizer to org.jvnet.inflector.lang.es.NounPluralizer.

Thanks
I was thinking that maybe taking the locale from the machine isn't the best idea always. Here I write programs with text in english and spanish. This has to be configurable.
And now I see the code it's not yours, so I have to ask to the inflector people to make the change. And maybe it's a dead project with last jar posted on Monday, July 24, 2006.

Stefan, we should have a chat about this. I need to understand your add-ons' requirements for pluralization, so we can properly provide it via PluralMetadata. That way future support for specifying a locale and/or providing explicit plurals can be consistent across the tool.

Is your only requirement for pluralization of property/field names and type names? Or is there something else as well?
Ben, currently there is indeed only a need to get the plural values for field/property and type names, so if BeanInfoMetadata could provide this that would be great.

I'm having the same problem with both the vote script and my own application.
I have no need for what kind of pluralization what so ever, but apparently it's part of the MVC addon. Since Inflector is probably a dead project, I would not want to use it anyway.

Is there a workaround somehow? It's really annoying files get removed again.

I'm experiencing the same error but for me it seems to work if I do the following

1. use only english names for entities and attributes
2. add the following to the "java" call in roo.bat/ roo.sh

-Duser.language=en -Duser.region=US

My roo.bat now looks the following:

@echo off

setlocal

set PROJECT_DIRECTORY="%cd%"

rem %~dp0 is location of current script under NT
set _REALPATH=%~dp0
set ROO_HOME=%_REALPATH%/..

cd %PROJECT_DIRECTORY%

echo Resolved ROO_HOME: %ROO_HOME%
echo Resolved PROJECT_DIRECTORY %PROJECT_DIRECTORY%

java -Duser.language=en -Duser.region=US -Djava.ext.dirs=%ROO_HOME%/lib;%ROO_HOME%/dist org.springframework.roo.bootstrap.Bootstrap "classpath:/roo-bootstrap.xml"

Nevertheless this is still a workaround! It would be much nicer if this was fixed very soon.

Greets,
Alex
This is now fixed in the trunk (as of revision 93) and has been tested with the German system locale.

I know 2 years have past. But, in this thread you guys are discussing Pluralizing Spanish and German, either using the Inflector library or maybe you found another way. Hernan specifically mentions adding Spanish support to Inflector which is exactly my requirement. If anyone could point me in a direction to help understand how this was resolved it would be much appreciated.

Thanks,
tom.
